channel.title: GLOBAL on The Encryption Compendium
channel.description: Recent content in GLOBAL on The Encryption Compendium

item.title: Big reputation: What the Australian Parliament Can Learn from Taylor Swift
item.description: Authors: Amie Stepanovich Published: February 2019 URL: https://www.accessnow.org/big-reputation-what-the-australian-parliament-can-learn-from-taylor-swift/ Abstract: Australia’s anti-encryption law lets law enforcement and intelligence agencies order companies to do just about anything in the pursuit of national security or enforcement of criminal law. Here’s a guide for enacting deep reform.

item.title: Cryptography and Liberty 2000: An International Survey of Encryption Policy
item.description: Authors: Wayne Madsen, David Banisar Published: 2000 URL: https://epic.org/reports/crypto2000.html/

item.title: CryptoMap: A Research on the Legal Debate Over Encryption
Encryption and Globalization
item.description: Authors: Swire, Peter P. and Ahmad, Kenesa Published: 2012 URL: http://www.ssrn.com/abstract=1960602

item.title: Encryption Restrictions
item.description: Authors: Messmer, Ellen Published: March 2004 URL: https://www.networkworld.com/article/2331257/encryption-restrictions.html Abstract: Regulations regarding the import and export of encryption products affect buying decisions worldwide.

item.title: Sources: We were pressured to weaken the mobile security in the 80's
item.description: Authors: Færaas, Arild Published: January 2014 URL: https://www.aftenposten.no/article/ap-Olkl.html Abstract: Four men who were part of a group that wrote mobile history tell for the first time how strong protection against eavesdropping of cell phones was weakened.

item.title: “Five Eyes” Governments Respond to Coalition Demands to Stop Undermining Encryption
item.description: Authors: Amie Stepanovich, Bennett Cyphers Published: October 2017 URL: https://www.accessnow.org/five-eyes-governments-respond-coalition-demands-stop-undermining-encryption/ Abstract: Status update on the Five Eyes governments’ position on encryption
